document.masterDocTitle: Revision of the genus Orthocephalus Fieber, 1858 (Hemiptera: Heteroptera: Miridae: Orthotylinae) 2316

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision of the genus Orthocephalus Fieber, 1858 (Hemiptera: Heteroptera: Miridae: Orthotylinae) 2316

subSubSection.paragraph:
Orthocephalus niger Reuter, 1879
A: 63, NEW SYNONYMY.

DIAGNOSIS: Distinguished by the aedeagus with both spicules shorter than dorsal wall of theca, long spicule straight, distinctly longer than other, short spicule somewhat curved (fig. 7) and the structure of dorsal labiate plate with a pair of medial sclerites two to three times as long as sclerotized ring (fig. 14). Pale males recognized by the yellowish stripe along claval suture, yellow antennal segment I, and tibiae often paler than femora. Darker specimens with dark brown antennal segment I and tibiae can be confused with
O. turkmenicus
in coloration, but that species differing from
O. bivittatus
in having spicules almost equal in length (fig. 7). Females hardly recognized by coloration, often having uniformly dark brown to black hemelytra and variable coloration of legs. Pale females most similar to
O. fulvipes
,
O. saltator ,
and
O. sefrensis
but these species can be distinguished in having medial sclerites equal to or slightly longer than sclerotized ring (figs. 15-17). Dark females apparently not separable from
O. turkmenicus
.

REDESCRIPTION: Male: Macropterous; length 4.6–5.5. COLORATION (fig. 1): Variable, from dark brown with pale areas on dorsum, antennae, and legs to almost uniformly dark. Head : Dark brown; vertex with yellowish or pale brown spot near inner margin of eye, sometimes barely visible; posterior margin of eye with yellowish or pale brown stripe; maxillary plate often with pale brown or yellowish stripe below antennal fossa; antennal segment I often yellowish with darker base, antennal segment II sometimes yellowish at base, in darkest specimens maxillary plate and antenna uniformly dark brown to black; labium dark brown. Thorax : Pronotum and pleurites dark brown; evaporatorium yellowish or pale brown, always paler than pleurites; scutellum dark brown; coxa dark brown; femur often dark brown to black, sometimes with pale apex, rarely femur pale with darker minute rounded spots; tibia often yellowish or pale brown, sometimes with darker apex and base, sometimes with small indistinct infuscation at base of spines, rarely tibia dark brown; tarsus dark brown to black; hemelytra with dirty yellow longitudinal stripe on outer part of clavus and inner half of corium, rarely very thin or indistinct; sometimes outer margin of corium with dirty yellow edging; apical part of membrane brown to dark brown, basal part paler, typically with several indistinctly bordered rounded dark spots, rarely membrane uniformly brown. Abdomen : Uniformly dark brown. SURFACE AND VESTITURE: Head and hemelytra smooth, pronotum and scutellum somewhat rugose. Dorsum, pleurites, and abdomen clothed with scalelike setae (as in figs. 22 A-C, E, 23 A, D); simple setae contrastingly long but often shorter than diameter of eye, bristlelike, dark and erect, distributed on head, antennal segments II-IV, pronotum, especially on lateral margins and anterior part, forecoxa, margins of femora, bases of hemelytra and abdomen, distinctly shorter on apical part of corium and cuneus; legs and antennal segment I with short, fine simple setae; antennal segment I with two black spines. STRUCTURE AND MEASUREMENTS: Body 3.4–3.9× as long as width of pronotum. Head : Relatively narrow, tapering, 1.2–1.3× as wide as high; frons convex; mandibular plate long and narrow; depression along hind margin of vertex weak, sometimes indistinct; eye located at a small distance from anterior pronotal margin, almost not protruding (figs. 20 B, 21 A, G); vertex 2.1–2.4× as wide as eye; antennal fossa located at a short distance from inferior margin of eye (fig. 20 B); antennal segment I as long as or somewhat longer than diameter of eye; antennal segment II thin, almost not incrassate, 0.9–1.1× as long as basal width of pronotum, 1.1–1.4× as long as width of head, labium reaching middle coxa. Thorax: Pronotum 2.0–2.4× as wide as long and 1.1–1.3× as wide as head, with posterior margin straight or slightly concave, lateral margins not carinate, calli slightly raised; hind femur relatively narrow, approximately 1.5× as wide as middle femur. GENITALIA: Aedeagus (fig. 7) with two gradually tapering spicules, both shorter than dorsal wall of theca, long spicule straight, almost twice as long as short one, directed to mouth of theca, short spicule smoothly curved, claw-shaped, directed to secondary gonopore; parameres as in fig. 10.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 3 . Habitus views of
Orthocephalus proserpinae
,
O. putshkovi
,
O. rhyparopus
.
O. scorzonerae
,
O. saltator
, and
O. solidus
.

subSubSection.paragraph: DISTRIBUTION: This species is distributed in a large territory from Western Europe in the west, to Novosibirsk Province and Altay Republic of Russia in the east, in Poland , Germany , Voronez , Kursk , Bashkortostan , Omsk , and Novosibirsk Provinces of Russia in the north, and south to Iraq ( Linnavuori, 1992 ), Iran ( Linnavuori and Modarres, 1999 ), Caucasus, and Central Asia.

HOSTS: Linnavuori and Modarres (1999) reported the species from Poaceae . Specimens from the collection of ZISP were sampled from
Achillea sp.
( Asteraceae ) and
Centaurea cyanus
L. ( Asteraceae ) by Akramovskaya,
Artemisia marschalliana Spreng.
( Asteraceae ) and
Artemisia lerchiana Webb.
( Asteraceae ) by Kerzhner, and from
Euphorbia splendens Boj.
ex. Hook ( Euphorbiaceae ) by L. V. Arnoldi.

DISCUSSION: This species shows great variability in appearance. In addition to patterns of coloration noted in the diagnosis, extremes of variation include uniformly dark brown males and females having yellowish femora with darkened minute spots. Externally these specimens are not separable from females of
O. vittipennis
but can be most readily distinguished by the structure of the male and female genitalia.

The original description of
O. niger Reuter, 1879
did not contain a comparison with
O. bivittatus ,
or distinguishing characters for these species.
Orthocephalus niger
was not noticed in any relevant keys or taxonomic papers published since the original description. We have not seen the syntypes of
O. bivittatus
, as it appears that they have been lost. However, our observations show that the lectotype and all available material of
O. niger
can not be separated from
O. bivittatus
both in appearance and genitalic structures. Therefore,
O. niger
is treated here as a junior synonym of
O. bivittatus .
